quote: Captain's log, stardate 42523.7.   We are in route to newly   established Starbase one-seven-three for port   call. Crew rotation is scheduled,   and we will offload experiment   modules.
Hold it, that's my chair. My luck   is always lousy unless I start   on the dealer's left.
That would seem to be rank   superstition.
Bitter experience has taught me   it's a fundamental truth.
(slapping the cards down     in front of O'Brien     who cuts them)   The game is five card stud,   nothing's wild.
This game is exceedingly simple.   With only fifty-two cards,   seventeen of which I will see,   and four players there are a   limited number of possible winning   combinations.
There's more to it than just the   cards.
The bets will give an indication   of the relative strengths of each   hand.
Time to pluck a pigeon.
I think I'm in trouble.
I'll raise five.
Too rich for me.
I will raise you three.
Your three and five more.
Is this what is known as the poker   face?
Are you playing or not?
I will fold.
You had nothing.
He bluffed you, Data.
It makes very little sense to bet   when you cannot win.
But I did win. I was gambling   that you wouldn't call.
But how can you tell?
Instinct, Data, instinct.       The game is seven card high/low   with a buy on the last card. And   just to make it interesting the   man with the axe takes all.
(with a little edge on     the words)   My God, if it isn't Phillipa   Louvois, back in uniform.
Don't gloat, Picard. It's almost   more irritating then when you're   being self-righteous.
Unbelievable, after all this time,   and we're picking up the threads   of old fights as if we'd never   been apart.
Ain't love wonderful.
What are you doing out here?
I'm in charge of the Sector   twenty-three JAG office. I'll   be making some good law.       And maybe do a little good along   the way, too. What do you think?
Anything is possible. You   returned to Starfleet.
I had to, it's the most exciting   and worthwhile place to be.
You didn't have to leave.
They forced me out.
No. That was your own damn   stubborn pride.
When I prosecuted you in the   Stargazer court-martial I was   doing my job.
No, you went way beyond doing the   job. You enjoyed it.
Not true! A court-martial is   standard when a ship has been   lost. I had a duty as an officer   in the Judge Advocate General.
Flummery, you've always enjoyed   the adversarial process more than   arriving at the truth.
Well, I hope you've learned a   little wisdom.
Watch it, you're doing it again.
(forcing a smile, and     we see the tension     leech from his body)   I'm not being self-righteous.   Merely right.
A distinction, I would submit,   without a difference.
Come and sit down.
I can't stay long. I'm meeting   someone for dinner.
But he hasn't arrived yet.
What makes you think it's a man?
Past experience.
Cute. Try to remember that you're   an officer and a gentleman.       You know, I never thought I would   say this, but it is good to see   you again. You're still a damn   sexy man, Picard.
So buy me dinner.
I thought you were meeting   someone?
(struggling with     herself)   Once again you're always right,   Jean-Luc.
Admiral.
Captain Louvois. You're   acquainted with Captain Picard?
Yes, we're old... friends.
Captain, good to see you again.   May I present Commander Bruce   Maddox. He has an interesting   proposal for you.
But that can wait until later.   I'm eager to see the Enterprise.
Admiral, Commander Maddox, allow   me to introduce my first officer,   Commander William Riker.
Pleasure, Commander.
How long has it been since we've   seen each other?
You'd just been assigned as an   ensign aboard the old Reliant.
Oh yes, and I seem to remember   a certain young lieutenant who   had harsh words about snap   inspections, and the admirals who   pulled them.
The situation changes when you've   got the admiral's stripes.
There isn't an officer in   Starfleet who wouldn't give his   right leg to be where you are -- Captain   of the Starship   Enterprise. I'm no different.   I just have the power to get   aboard.
Happy to have you, Admiral.
Bridge. Congratulations on your   appointment. Command of a   Starbase.
Thank you, but I miss a ship.   A bit of advice, Captain. Don't   ever become an admiral. They make   you an administrator.
Admiral on the bridge.
I was a little surprised at the   decision to put a base in force   this close to the Neutral Zone.
As you know, we've had disturbing   news from both sides of the zone.   We're here to respond as needed.   And it won't hurt to have the   Romulans know we're nearby.
Well, Captain, I thank you for   this opportunity. For five   hundred years ships who've borne   the name Enterprise have been a   legend. This one is no different.
Admiral.
Oh yes, Captain. Commander Maddox   is here to do some work on your   android. Please take care of him.
Lieutenant Worf.
How have you been, Data?
My condition does not alter with   the passage of time, Commander.
The two of you are acquainted?
Yes, I evaluated Data when it   first applied to the Academy.
And were the sole member of the   committee to oppose my entrance   on the grounds that I was not a   sentient being.
What exactly will this work   entail?
I'm going to disassemble Data.
(pausing for a beat to     assimilate this)   I think we will remove this   discussion to the lounge.
Explain this procedure.

Ever since I first saw Data at   its entrance evaluation at   Starfleet Academy, I've wanted   to understand it. I became a   student of the works of Doctor   Noonien Soong -- Data's creator.   I've tried to continue his work,   and I believe I am very close to   the breakthrough which will enable   me to duplicate Soong's work and   replicate this.       But as a first step I must   disassemble and study it. Data   is going to be my guide.
Data?
It sounds intriguing.
How will you proceed?

I'll run a full diagnostic on   Data, evaluating the condition   of its software. I'll then dump   its core memory into the starbase   mainframe computer and begin a   detailed analysis of its   construction.
You have constructed a positronic   brain?
Yes.
Have you determined how the   electron resistance across the   neural filaments is to be   resolved?
Not precisely.
That would seem to be a necessary   first step.
I'm confident that I'll have the   answer once I've examine the   filament links in your anterior   cortex.
But if the answer is not   forthcoming, your model will not   function.
I don't anticipate a problem.
You seem a little vague on the   specifics. What are the risks   to Commander Data?
Negligible.
His basic research lacks the   specifics necessary to support   an experiment of this magnitude.
Data is a valued member of my   bridge crew. Based on what I've   heard I cannot allow him to submit   to your experiment.

I thought this might be your   attitude, Captain.    (he removes a message     disk from his pocket,     and extends it to     Picard)   Here are Starfleet's transfer   orders separating Commander Data   from the Enterprise, and   reassigning it to Starbase one-seven-three   under my command. Data, I'll   expect you in my office at nine   hundred hours tomorrow.
Look, it's a transfer, like any   other transfer.
No, it's not. This is one of my   key officers, and he's been   removed without consulting me.

I'm sorry about that, but   Commander Maddox's work in   robotics is considered critical   by Starfleet Command. Think   what's at stake here. If   Commander Maddox can succeed in   duplicating Noonien Soong's work   other captains on other ships   would have the advantage you now   enjoy: a Data on every bridge.   You don't want Data transferred,   fine. There's an easy solution.   Have him work with Commander   Maddox. Nakamura out.
Come.
You sent for me, sir?
Please, sit down. We've got a   problem.
I find myself in agreement with   that assessment of the situation,   sir.
Your service to this ship has been   exemplary. I don't want to lose   you.
I am pleased to hear you say so.   Thank you.
There is a solution which presents   itself.
Yes, sir?
Undergo the procedure, then the   transfer order becomes moot.
I will not submit to this   procedure.

Data, I understand your objections   to this procedure, but I also have   to consider Starfleet's interests.   If Commander Maddox is correct   there is a possibility that many   more beings such as yourself could   be constructed.
True, but possibility is a word   which can encompass any number   of outcomes -- good and bad.
But if he's right, Starfleet would   be immeasurably enriched.
Captain, I am a Starfleet   officer. Can they force me to   do this?
It's precisely because you are   a Starfleet officer that they can.   We take an oath to serve. In this   case this is the form your service   is taking.
Sir, Lieutenant La Forge's eyes   are far superior to human   biological eyes, true?
Yes.
Then why are not all human   officers required to have their   eyes replaced with cybernetic   implants?
I see. It is precisely because   I am not human.
That will be all, Mister Data.    (jabs open the com     on his desk)   Computer. Pull all relevant   Starfleet regulations concerning   officer transfers.
Working.
My God, twice in as many days.
I need your help.
An historic moment.

I've been trying to make heads   or tails of this gibberish, and   it's finally defeated me. My   android officer has been   transferred so he can undergo a   highly dangerous procedure. I   want to stop it.
He can refuse to undergo this   procedure, but we can't stop the   transfer.
Once Maddox has Data under his   control anything could happen.   I don't trust that man.
We agree to certain risks when   we join Starfleet.
Acceptable risks, justified risks,   yes, but I can't accept this.   It's unfair and unjust. What   about his rights...
All this passion over a machine.
(raising a warning     finger)   Don't start. Is there an option?
There's always an option. He can   resign.
So you came to me for help.
(stiff because he thinks     she's taunting him)   Yes, I came to you. You're the   JAG officer in this sector. I had   to come to you.
Wait! I didn't mean it that way.   I'm... I'm glad that you thought   you could... well, come to me.
Trust is too painful a word.
I wish things were different for   us.
"When in disgrace with fortune     and men's eyes,   I all alone beweep my outcast     state... "   Is it just words to you, or do   you fathom the meaning?
It is customary to request   permission before entering an   individual's quarters.
I thought we could talk this out,   that I could try to reassure you.   Your memories and knowledge will   remain intact.
Reduced to mere sterile facts   of the events. The substance,   the flavor of the moment could   be lost. Take games of chance...
Games of chance?

Yes, I had read and absorbed every   treatise and textbook upon the   subject, and felt myself tolerably   well prepared for the experience.   Yet, when I finally played poker,   I discovered that the reality bore   little resemblance to the rules.
The point being?

That while I believe that you can   download the information contained   in the positronic brain, I do not   think you have acquired the   expertise necessary to preserve   the heart of those experiences.   There is an ineffable quality to   memory that I do not believe can   survive the shutdown of my core.
(looking at Data with     wonder)   Ineffable quality. I would   rather that we had done this   together, but one way or the other   we are doing it. You're under   my command.
No, sir, I am not under your nor   anyone else's command. I have   resigned from Starfleet.
Resigned. You can't.

I regret the decision, but I must.   I am the culmination of one man's   dream. This is not ego or vanity,   but when Doctor Soong created me   he added to the substance of the   universe. If by your experiments   I am destroyed, something unique   and wonderful will be lost. I   cannot permit that, I must protect   the dream.
And so must I. Keep packing,   you will be reporting.

Captain's log, supplemental.   Commander Bruce Maddox, having   been thwarted by Data's abrupt   resignation from Starfleet is now   seeking a legal remedy for his   woes. Captain Louvois has   requested my presence at those   discussions.

Your response is emotional and   irrational. You're endowing Data   with human characteristics because   it looks human. But it's not.   If it were a box on wheels I   wouldn't be facing this   opposition.
Overt sentimentalism is not one   of Captain Picard's failings.   Trust me, I know.
Data is a valued member of my   crew, an outstanding bridge   officer, a --

If I'm permitted to make this   experiment the horizons for human   achievement become boundless.   Consider, every ship in the   Federation with a Data on board.   Utilizing their tremendous   capabilities. Acting as our hands   and eyes in dangerous situations.   That is worth a little   inconvenience.
Look, you're preaching to the   choir here.       So why don't you get to the point?
(palms flat on the desk     he leans in on her)   Data must not be permitted to   resign.
He's an officer in Starfleet.   He has certain rights...
Rights! Rights! I'm sick to   death of hearing about rights!   What about my right not to have   my life work subverted by blind   ignorance?
We have rule of law in this   Federation. You can't simply   seize people, and experiment with   them to prove your pet theories.

Now you're doing it. Data is an   extraordinary piece of   engineering, but it is a machine.   If you permit it to resign it will   destroy years of work in robotics.   Starfleet doesn't have to allow   the resignation --

Starfleet is not an organization   that ignores its own regulations   when they become inconvenient.   Whether you like it or not, Data    (separating and     punctuating each word)   does... have... rights.
(visibly calming himself     and ignoring Picard)   Let me put it another way. Would   you permit the computer on the   Enterprise to refuse a refit?
An interesting point, but the   Enterprise computer is property.   Is Data?
Of course.
There might be law to support that   position.

A decision with such broad-ranging   implications must be supported   by an official ruling.       And I trust you will apply the   same zeal to your research that   you used during the Stargazer   court-martial.
You're supposed to rip the   wrapping off a present.
But with the application of a   little care, Wes, the paper can   be utilized again.
You're missing the point.
The Dream of the Fire, by K'Ratak.   Thank you, Worf.
It was in the hands of the   Klingons that the novel attained   its full stature.
I couldn't disagree more, but   we'll save that argument for   another day. Now listen   carefully. I didn't get you a   present --
That is quite all right. None   was expected...

Instead I'm going to give you   something far more valuable -- my   advice. You've spent years   in the womb of Starfleet. Now   you're about to start a new life.   You'd be wise to consider the   experiences offered by   groundside living.
Thank you. I will take that under   advisement.    (noticing Geordi sitting     alone in a corner     nursing a drink)   Excuse me, please.       Is something wrong?
Of course there is. You're going   away.
No one regrets the necessity more   than I, but you do understand my   reasons?
Oh yeah, I understand. I just   don't like your being forced out.   It's not fair.
Doctor Pulaski would, at this   juncture, no doubt remind us that   life is rarely fair.
Sorry, but that doesn't make it   any easier.
(slowly, a little     awkwardly)   I shall... miss you.
Me too.    (he gives Data a fierce     hug)   You take care, Data.
Deanna... does Data have...   do you feel anything from him?
I can't sense anything from Data.   But that proves nothing. There   are many minds from which I can   read no meaning.
There's got to be more to him than   software, nets and chips.
It is possible that Commander   Maddox is correct and we are   anthropomorphizing Data.   Assigning to him emotions and   responses which he may not have.
I'm not sure I see that as a   problem.
A little farewell celebration?
Yes, to which I don't recall   inviting you.
I couldn't miss this. I can't   wait to hear Data's plans.

They are currently somewhat   indefinite, but my programming   offers a number of alternatives.    (crossing to Wesley,     and dropping an arm     over the boy's     shoulders)   I am considering teaching. I have   had some success with my star   pupil.
I have a better idea. Carnival   work. They could bill you as the   walking encyclopedia. Ask him   any question --
Number One, Captain Louvois has   called. We're expected in her   office. Meet me in Transporter   Room Five.
On my way.       I know you're just leaving. I'll   escort you.

I have completed my research,   and based on the Acts of Gould   passed in the early twenty-first   century, Data is the property of   Starfleet. He cannot resign and   he cannot refuse to cooperate with   Commander Maddox.
And if I challenge this ruling?
I will be required to hold a   hearing.
Then I so challenge. Convene your   hearing.
Captain, that would be exceedingly   difficult. This is a new base.   I have no staff --
Surely there are regulations to   cover this eventuality.
There are. I can use serving   officers as legal counsel. You   as senior officer would defend.
Very well.
And who gets the unenviable task   of prosecuting this case?
You do. The next most senior   officer aboard defendant's ship.
I can't. I won't. Data's my   friend, my comrade. We've served   together and I not only respect   him, I have affection for him.
This isn't about friendship. This   is about duty, and how we search   for truth.
A system that pits people against   each other can't be the answer.
When people of good conscience   have an honest dispute we   sometimes must resort to this kind   of adversarial system.

You want me to try and prove that   Data's a mere machine. I can't.   I don't believe it. I know he's   more than that. I'm neither   qualified nor willing to do this.   You're going to have to find   someone else.
Then I'll rule summarily based   upon my findings. Data's a   toaster. Have him report to   Commander Maddox immediately for   experimental refit.
I see I have no choice but to   agree.
Good. But you better do your duty   in that courtroom. If I think   for one minute that you're not   giving me your best effort I'll   end this right then and there.
You don't have to remind us of   our duty. Just remember yours.
I've never forgotten it. Not   then, and certainly not now.

(cutting straight to     the heart of the     matter, with no attempt     to soften the blow)   Captain Louvois has issued a   ruling that you are the property   of Starfleet Command. You can't   resign.
I see... from limitless options   I am reduced to none, or rather   one. I can only hope that   Commander Maddox is more capable   than it would appear.

No, you're not going to submit.   We're going to fight this.   Captain Louvois may be overly   attached to the letter of the law,   but she has not forgotten its   spirit. She's convening a hearing   and we are going to lay the   question of your legal status to   rest once and for all.    (he rises, and paces     away, turns back, and     adds uncomfortably)   I have been asked to represent   you, but if there is some other   officer with whom you would feel   more comfortable --
Captain, I have complete   confidence in your ability to   represent my interests.
Care to try your hand, Number   One?
Another time. It's too close to   our real contest.
(exchanging blows with     his opponent)   This isn't about you and me.
Isn't it? Data may be the issue,   but our performances are what will   be judged.
(exchanging several     lightning blows with     his opponent)   That's the nature of the   adversarial process.
Which can only work when the   opponents are of equal ability.
(turning very slowly,     leaning on his sword     and regarding Riker)   Are you suggesting that we are   not evenly matched?
No, but for Data's sake it has   to be said. I've been forced into   this, and I have only one option.   To give this my best effort.
I see.       Then... you are here...       to warn me...       that you are going to do...       Everything within your power and   within the boundaries of the   law...       to win!
Yes.
So am I.
All right, I'm going to need to   know everything about you.
Sir, all of that information is   stored in the Enterprise computer   banks.
I want to hear it from you.

(cocking his head like     a puzzled bird)   Very good, sir. Activation   occurred twenty-seven years ago   on Omicron Theta. I entered the   Academy in '44, and graduated in   '48 with honors in probability   mechanics and exobiology. First   posting...
Data, Data, Data, whoa, stop.   I could get this from the   computer.
I believe I indicated that   earlier, sir.
I need to know how you think,   what you want, how you feel. What   drives you, motivates you.
Drives? Motivates? Sir, may I   inquire as to the purpose of this   line of questioning?
We have to prove that you're a   sentient life-form.
But I am not. I am a machine.
That's not what I need to hear.
How can we deny the obvious?
We're searching for an argument   which will legally deny that   obvious fact.
But if it is a fact how can   argument alter --
Data!
Sir?

Stop babbling.    (rewinding the threads     of his fast-tattering     patience)   The law recognizes many things   as people that aren't possessed   of flesh and blood. It's a little   legal fiction, you see.
I am beginning to understand why   Shakespeare wrote, let us kill   all the lawyers.
Computer, identify Riker, William   T. Clearance level blue.
Identified. Ready.
Access all technical schematics   of Lieutenant Commander Data.
Working.

Personal log. Zero three hundred.   I should be resting. Instead I   continue to prepare for a duty   I do not wish to perform. Truth   should not be reduced to a prize   in a battle of wills and words.
All rise.
(seats herself behind     the bench)   Be seated. Counselors, are you   ready?
We are, your honor.

This hearing convened on stardate   42524.1 is to determine the legal   status of the android known as   Data. The office of the Judge   Advocate General has rendered a   finding of property, defense has   challenged. Commander Riker.
Your honor, there is only one   issue in this case and one   relevant piece of evidence. I   call Lieutenant Commander Data.
Verify, Lieutenant Commander Data.   Current assignment, USS   Enterprise. Starfleet Command   Decoration for...
Your honor, we'll stipulate to   all of this.
Objection, your honor, I want it   read. All of it.
Sustained.
... Gallantry, Medal of Honor with   clusters, Legion of Honor, the   Star Cross.
Commander Data, what are you?
(looking to Picard for     guidance, Picard nods     to him to answer)   An android.
Which is?
Webster's Twenty-Third Century   Dictionary, Fifth Edition, defines   Android as an automaton made to   resemble a human being.
An automaton. Made. Made by   whom?
Sir?
Who built you, Data?
Doctor Noonien Soong.
And he was?
The foremost authority in   cybernetics.
More basic than that. What was   he?
(puzzled, but groping     for the right answer;     he says questioningly)   A human?
Thank you. Data, what is the   capacity of your memory, and how   fast can you process information?
I have an ultimate storage   capacity of eight hundred   quadrillion bits. My total linear   computational speed has been rated   at sixty trillion operations per   second.
Your honor, I offer into evidence   prosecution's exhibit A. A bar   of plasteel with a tensile   strength of forty kilo-bars.
Commander Data, would you please   bend that.
Objection, your honor. Many races   possess meta-human strength. It's   not relevant to the issue before   this court.
I'm afraid I can't agree, Captain.   Proceed with the demonstration,   Commander Riker.

Drawing on the log record of the   construction of the prototype   android Lore, also constructed   by Noonien Soong, I request that   I be allowed to remove Commander   Data's hand for your inspection.
Objection! What is the point of   all this?
The issue before this court is   whether Data is machine, and by   extension property. I'd say this   is pretty damn relevant.
I'm sorry.

Data is a physical representation   of a dream, an idea conceived of   by the mind of a man. His   purpose? To serve human needs   and interests. He is a collection   of neural nets and heuristic   algorithms. His responses are   dictated by an elaborate software   program written by a man. The   hardware    (slapping the hand     against his palm)   was built by a man.
And this man has turned him off.   Pinocchio is broken, the strings   are cut.
I request a recess.
Granted.
You should get some sleep.
I've lost, and I'm not even sure   I mind. Data is a machine. But   there is something bothering me.   Something I'm missing. Or is it   just wounded pride that I've lost   and in front of her.
What is it that lies between you?
Ancient history.
Unfortunately the past always   resonates in the present, and   decisions made today reach into   the future.

(Drumming fingers on     the table, abruptly     he decides to tell her.     It emerges in sharp     staccato.)   The Stargazer court-martial. It   should have been a routine   hearing. Yes, I had lost my ship,   but my actions were entirely   justified.

Phillipa was assistant to the   prosecution. She dug up every   obscure case and citation and the   panel hammered at me for three   days. It damn near ended my   career. It did end us. She's   enjoying this situation. She   knows I disapprove of the   adversarial system. Now she's   forced me into active   participation, and she's both   pleased and angered to see me fail.
Emotions. They're such slippery,   contradictory things. It's a   wonder any of us ever crawled out   of the oceans, or swung down out   of the trees.
Well, there's only one thing to   do. I go to her in the morning,   and we discuss a deal.
(thoughtfully studying     her hands)   I had heard a lot about you before   I joined the Enterprise. About   how Picard was a man who never   knew when to lie down and admit   he was beat.

I have to salvage at least some   of Data's rights. If Data agrees   to undergo Commander Maddox's   procedure we can get out of this   hearing before he's declared the   property of Starfleet command.
If Commander Maddox is successful   in disassembling and reassembling   Data, what has he gained?
The ability to build another.   A hundred others, a thousand.
To do what?
Explore for us. Enter the   dangerous situations.
All those future Datas risking   their lives for the people who   created them.
You said something earlier about   decisions today.
Having implications for the   future.
Precedent! This case will set   the precedent for all the future   Datas. It will determine their   status, and they'll all be   property.
There is an ancient word for it -- slavery.
Not a word we want back in our   vocabulary.
Good luck, sir.

(making his opening     statement)   Commander Riker has dramatically   demonstrated to this court that   Lieutenant Commander Data is a   machine. Do we deny that? No.   But how is this relevant? We too   are machines, just machines of   a different type. Commander Riker   has continually reminded us that   Data was built by a human. We   do not deny that fact. But again   how is it relevant? Does   construction imply ownership?   Children are created from the   building blocks of their parents'   DNA. Are they property? We have   a chance in this hearing to   severely limit the boundaries   of freedom. And I think we   better be pretty damn careful   before we take so arrogant a step.   I call Lieutenant Commander Data   to the stand.
(continuing; lifts out     the case of medals,     and displays the     contents)   What are these, please?
My medals.
Why pack them? What logical   purpose do they serve?
I... I do not know, sir. None   I suppose. I just wanted them.   Is that vanity?
(holding up the book     of sonnets)   And this?
It was a gift from you, sir.
You value it?
Yes, sir.
Why?
It is a reminder of friendship   and service.
(lifts out the holocube,     and triggers it; Tasha     stands before them)   And this? You have no portraits   of any other of your crewmates.   Why this person?
I would prefer not to answer that   question, sir. I gave my word.
Mister Data, may I remind you, that   you are under oath.       And under the circumstances, I   don't think Tasha would mind.
(swallowing convulsively     several times)   She was important to me... we   were... intimate.
I have no further questions of   this witness.
Commander Riker, do you wish to   cross?
I have no questions, your honor.
I call to the stand Commander   Bruce Maddox as a hostile witness.
Verify, Maddox, Bruce, Commander.   Current assignment, Chair of   Robotics, Federation Institute   of Technology. Major papers...

Enough. Suffice it to say, he's   an expert.       Commander Maddox, it is your   contention that Data is not a   sentient being and therefore not   entitled to those rights reserved   for all other life-forms in this   Federation?
Data is not sentient, no.
Why, Commander?
Because Data is a piece of   outstanding engineering and   programming.
What is required for sentience?
Intelligence, self awareness,   consciousness.
Do you know what sentience is,   Commander?
Of course.
Excellent. Then you can enlighten   the rest of us.
(continuing; right in     Maddox's face)   Prove to this court that I'm   sentient.
This is absurd!
Why? Because you can't do it?
No, it's just pointless. We all   know you're sentient.
So I'm sentient, but Data isn't?
That's right.
Why?
Well... well, you're self aware.
